title: HTTP 100-continue handling for large uploads
description:
Handle Expect: 100-continue header for large POST/PUT requests. Server should validate auth/content-type before telling client to send body, saving bandwidth on rejected requests.

**Implementation:**
- Check Expect header during request line parsing
- If 100-continue present, pause before body read
- Call pre-body validation hooks (auth, content-type check)
- Send '100 Continue' response if validation passes
- Send 417 Expectation Failed if validation fails
- Then proceed to read body

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Expect: 100-continue handled correctly
- Pre-body validation hooks called before 100 response
- 417 sent when validation fails
- Normal requests without Expect work unchanged
- Integration with auth middleware

**Tests:**
- POST with Expect gets 100 then proceeds
- POST with Expect and bad auth gets 401, no body read
- POST without Expect works normally
- Large upload with 100-continue completes successfully

title: Error handling with Outcome integration
description:
Integrate asupersync's 4-valued Outcome for error handling:

## Outcome Mapping
- Outcome::Ok(response) - Successful response
- Outcome::Err(error) - Application/validation error -> HTTP error response
- Outcome::Cancelled(reason) - Client disconnect/timeout -> 499 or 504
- Outcome::Panicked(info) - Handler panic -> 500 Internal Server Error

## Error Conversion
- HTTPException -> Outcome::Err with status code
- RequestValidationError -> Outcome::Err with 422
- CancelledError -> Outcome::Cancelled
- panic!() -> Outcome::Panicked (caught by region)

## Cancel Reasons
- Client disconnected -> CancelReason::user("client disconnected")
- Budget exhausted -> CancelReason::budget_exhausted()
- Server shutdown -> CancelReason::user("server shutdown")

## Test Requirements
- Unit: Each Outcome variant mapped correctly
- Unit: Error types produce correct HTTP status
- Integration: Cancelled request cleanup
- Integration: Panic recovery
acceptance_criteria: Request cancellation produces Outcome::Cancelled, errors produce Outcome::Err.

- Synchronizer token pattern support

- Safe methods (GET, HEAD, OPTIONS) exempt
- Configurable token header name (X-CSRF-Token)

**Modes:**
1. Double Submit Cookie: Token in cookie + header must match
2. Synchronizer Token: Token stored server-side in session
3. SameSite Cookie: Rely on SameSite=Strict cookies

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- CSRF token generated and validated
- POST/PUT/DELETE require valid token
- GET/HEAD/OPTIONS exempt
- Token rotation on each request (configurable)
- Integration with form responses
- Clear error message on CSRF failure

**Tests:**

- POST with valid CSRF token succeeds
- GET request works without token
- Token mismatch returns 403

title: BackgroundTasks for post-response work
description:
Implement background task scheduling:

USAGE:
async fn handler(tasks: BackgroundTasks) -> Json<Response> {
    tasks.add(send_email, args);
    tasks.add(update_stats, args);
    Json(response) // Returns immediately, tasks run after
}

STRUCTURE:
BackgroundTasks {
    tasks: Vec<Box<dyn FnOnce() -> BoxFuture<'static, ()>>>,
}

EXECUTION:
- Tasks run AFTER response is sent to client
- Run in same region as request (asupersync)
- Errors logged but don't affect response
- Tasks can be async

INTEGRATION WITH ASUPERSYNC:
- Spawn tasks using Cx
- Tasks inherit region but run after response
- Region cancellation cancels pending tasks
- Budget allows graceful completion

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Response sent before tasks run
- Task errors don't affect response
- Works with asupersync structured concurrency
- Multiple tasks per request

TEST REQUIREMENTS:

title: TCP server with asupersync
description:
Implement TcpServer using asupersync's IO primitives:

## Server Architecture
- Main region owns the listener
- Each connection spawns a sub-region
- Each request within connection spawns a task
- Cx passed to request handlers via RequestContext

## Region Hierarchy
```
Server Region (root)
 Connection Region 1
    Request Task 1 (with Cx, Budget)
    Request Task 2 (with Cx, Budget)
    ...
 Connection Region 2
    ...
 ...
```

## Request Lifecycle
1. Accept connection, create connection region
2. Parse HTTP request
3. Create RequestContext with fresh Cx and request_id
4. Spawn request task with Budget
5. Route and execute handler
6. Send response
7. Task completes, region cleanup runs

## Configuration
- Bind address and port
- Backlog size
- Default request budget

## Test Requirements
- Unit: Connection acceptance
- Unit: Region hierarchy
- Integration: Multiple concurrent requests
- Integration: Request isolation
acceptance_criteria: Server accepts connections, each request runs in its own region with proper cleanup.

title: Router inclusion with config merging

    prefix: '/api/v1',
    tags: ['api'],
    dependencies: [auth_dep],
    responses: {...},
    deprecated: Some(false),
})

MERGE RULES (per FastAPI spec):
1. prefix: prepended to router's prefix
2. tags: prepended to router's tags
3. dependencies: prepended to router's dependencies
4. responses: merged (route > router > app)
5. deprecated: override if provided
6. include_in_schema: override if provided

RECURSION:
- Routers can include other routers
- Configs merge at each level
- Path: /api/v1 + /users + /{id} = /api/v1/users/{id}

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:

    async fn setup(ctx: &RequestContext) -> (Self::Value, CleanupFn);
}

OR use a scoped pattern:
async fn with_db_connection<F, R>(ctx: &RequestContext, f: F) -> R
where F: FnOnce(DbConnection) -> Future<Output = R>

EXIT STACK:
- Register cleanup functions during dependency resolution
- Run all cleanups after handler completes (LIFO order)
- Run cleanups even on error/panic
- Integrate with asupersync's structured concurrency

COMMON USE CASES:
- Database connections (return to pool)
- File handles (close)
- Locks (release)
- Transactions (commit/rollback)

title: Implement Depends extractor for DI
description:
Implement Depends<T> extractor for dependency injection:

STRUCTURE:
Depends<T, Config = DefaultConfig> where T: FromDependency

Config options:
- use_cache: bool = true
- scope: Option<Scope> ('function' | 'request')

FromDependency TRAIT:
pub trait FromDependency: Sized + Send {
    type Error: IntoResponse;
    async fn from_dependency(ctx: &RequestContext) -> Result<Self, Self::Error>;
}

RESOLUTION:
1. Check dependency_overrides for substitution
2. Check cache (if use_cache && scope matches)
3. Call FromDependency::from_dependency
4. Store in cache
5. Return value

NESTED DEPENDENCIES:
Depends<A> where A depends on Depends<B>
- B resolved first
- A receives B as parameter

HANDLER USAGE:
async fn handler(db: Depends<DbPool>, user: Depends<CurrentUser>) -> Json<Data>

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Basic resolution works
- Caching per request scope
- Nested dependencies resolve
- Overrides for testing work
- Async dependencies work

TEST REQUIREMENTS:
- Unit: Basic resolution
- Unit: Caching behavior
- Unit: Nested resolution
- Unit: Override substitution
- Unit: Error handling
- Integration: Complex dependency graph
- Integration: Async factory functions
acceptance_criteria: Depends<DbConn> resolves from app state, caches per request.

title: Implement OpenAPI document builder
description:

OpenApiBuilder {
    title: String,
    version: String,

    contact: Option<Contact>,
    license: Option<License>,
    servers: Vec<Server>,
    tags: Vec<TagDefinition>,
    external_docs: Option<ExternalDocs>,
}

COLLECTION PROCESS:
1. Iterate all registered routes
2. For each route, collect:
   - Path parameters (with types/constraints)
   - Query parameters (with validation rules)
   - Header parameters
   - Request body schema
   - Response schemas (by status code)
   - Security requirements
3. Deduplicate schemas into components/schemas
4. Build paths object
5. Assemble final document

SCHEMA DEDUPLICATION:
- Track all referenced types
- Generate $ref for repeated types
- Place definitions in components/schemas
- Use type name as schema key

OPERATION ID GENERATION:
Default: {function_name}_{path}_{methods}
Custom via operation_id parameter

ENDPOINT:
- GET /openapi.json returns document
- Optional: /docs redirects to Swagger UI

QUERY EXAMPLE:

query: String
// Accepts ?q=value instead of ?query=value

ALIAS PROPAGATION:
if alias is set and serialization_alias is None:
    serialization_alias = alias
if alias is set and validation_alias is None:

title: RequestValidationError with location tuples
description:
Implement validation error aggregation:

STRUCTURE:
- errors: Vec<ValidationErrorItem>
- body: Option<serde_json::Value> (the invalid input)

ValidationErrorItem:
- type_: String (error type: 'missing', 'string_too_short', etc)
- loc: Vec<LocItem> (location: ['body', 'field', 'nested'])
- msg: String (human-readable message)
- input: serde_json::Value (the invalid value)
- ctx: Option<HashMap> (constraint context)

LocItem enum:
- String(String) for field names
- Int(usize) for array indices

LOCATION PREFIXES (per FastAPI):
- Path params: ['path', 'param_name']
- Query params: ['query', 'param_name']
- Headers: ['header', 'header_name']
- Cookies: ['cookie', 'cookie_name']
- Body: ['body'] or ['body', 'field', 'nested']

RESPONSE FORMAT (422):
{
  "detail": [
    {"type": "missing", "loc": ["query", "q"], "msg": "Field required", "input": null}
  ]
}

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Errors collected from all extractors
- Proper location tuples
- FastAPI-compatible JSON format
- Multiple errors aggregated

TEST REQUIREMENTS:
- Unit: Each error type formatting
- Unit: Nested location paths
- Unit: Array index locations
- Integration: Multiple validation errors
- Compatibility: Match FastAPI format exactly

title: Implement derive macro for Validate trait
description:
Create proc macro for validation derive:

ATTRIBUTE SYNTAX:
#[derive(Validate)]
struct CreateUser {
    #[validate(length(min = 1, max = 100))]
    name: String,
    
    #[validate(email)]
    email: String,
    
    #[validate(range(ge = 0, le = 150))]
    age: i32,
    
    #[validate(regex = r'^[a-z]+$')]
    username: String,
    
    #[validate(custom = validate_password)]
    password: String,
    
    #[validate(nested)]
    address: Address,
}

SUPPORTED VALIDATORS:
- length(min, max) - String/Vec length
- range(gt, ge, lt, le) - Numeric bounds
- email - Email format
- url - URL format
- regex = 'pattern' - Regex match
- custom = function - Custom validator
- nested - Validate nested struct
- multiple_of = N - Divisibility check

ERROR GENERATION:
Each validator generates ValidationErrorItem with:
- type_: validator name
- loc: field path
- msg: human-readable message
- ctx: constraint values

GENERATED CODE:
impl Validate for CreateUser {
    fn validate(&self) -> Result<(), ValidationErrors> {
        let mut errors = vec![];
        if self.name.len() < 1 { errors.push(...); }
        if self.name.len() > 100 { errors.push(...); }
        // ... more validations
        if errors.is_empty() { Ok(()) } else { Err(ValidationErrors(errors)) }
    }
}

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All validators generate correct code
- Error messages are clear
- Nested validation works
- Custom validators supported
- Compile-time field type checking

TEST REQUIREMENTS:
- Unit: Each validator type
- Unit: Multiple validators per field
- Unit: Nested struct validation
- Unit: Custom validator integration
- Unit: Error message quality
- Compile-fail: Invalid attribute usage
acceptance_criteria: derive(Validate) generates working validators with descriptive errors.

title: Request timeout via Budget
description:
Use asupersync's Budget for request timeouts:

## Budget Configuration
- Default budget per request (configurable)
- Budget propagates through handler and dependencies
- Remaining budget accessible via RequestContext.budget()

## Timeout Behavior
- Budget exhaustion triggers cancellation
- Handler receives CancelledError at next checkpoint
- Response: 504 Gateway Timeout with configurable body
- Clean resource cleanup via structured concurrency

## Integration Points
- TCP server creates budget for each request
- Middleware chain respects budget
- Extractors check budget before expensive operations
- Dependencies can subdivide budget

## Test Requirements
- Unit: Budget creation and propagation
- Unit: Timeout triggers cancellation
- Integration: Slow handler returns 504
- Integration: Cleanup runs on timeout
acceptance_criteria: Slow handlers cancelled when budget exhausted, return 504.

title: Checkpoint integration in extractors and middleware
description: Integrate cancellation checkpoints throughout the request pipeline for cancel-correctness. Checkpoint locations: before body read, after body parse, before each dependency resolve, before handler call, in middleware pre/post. Use ctx.checkpoint() to allow graceful cancellation. Masked sections: transaction commits, response send. Benefits: early exit on client disconnect, clean resource cleanup. Test: verify checkpoint returns CancelledError when cancelled, masked sections complete, resources cleaned up.

title: Scope constraint validation
description:
Enforce dependency scope constraints:

RULE (per FastAPI spec):
Request-scoped dependency CANNOT depend on function-scoped dependency.
This would cause the request-scoped to hold stale function-scoped value.

EXAMPLE VIOLATION:
@depends(scope='request')
async fn get_cached_user(db: Depends<DbConn, scope='function'>) -> User
// ERROR: request scope can't depend on function scope

VALIDATION:
- Check at dependency graph construction
- Raise DependencyScopeError
- Clear message explaining the violation

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Scope violation detected at startup
- Clear error message
- Explain why it's invalid
- Allow valid scope combinations

TEST REQUIREMENTS:
- Unit: Invalid scope combination
- Unit: Valid scope combinations
- Unit: Nested scope validation

title: Graceful shutdown with structured concurrency
description:
Graceful shutdown using asupersync's structured concurrency:

## Shutdown Phases
1. Stop accepting new connections
2. Set shutdown flag (new requests get 503)
3. Wait for in-flight requests (with grace period)
4. Cancel remaining requests after grace period
5. Run shutdown hooks
6. Close server region

## Signal Handling
- SIGTERM/SIGINT triggers shutdown
- Second signal forces immediate exit
- Configurable signals

## Grace Period
- Default: 30 seconds
- Requests get remaining budget subdivided
- Requests exceeding grace get cancelled

## Region Closing
- Connection regions closed when idle
- Request tasks cancelled with CancelReason::shutdown
- Cleanup handlers run for all regions

## Test Requirements
- Unit: Shutdown signal handling
- Unit: Grace period enforcement
- Integration: In-flight requests complete
- Integration: Stuck requests cancelled
acceptance_criteria: Server shutdown waits for requests with budget, then cancels remaining.

title: Custom exception handlers registry
description:
Implement custom exception handler registration:

app.exception_handler(MyError, my_handler)
app.exception_handler(HttpError, custom_http_handler)

HANDLER SIGNATURE:
async fn handler(ctx: &RequestContext, err: MyError) -> Response

DEFAULT HANDLERS:
- HttpError -> JSON response with status/detail
- RequestValidationError -> 422 with error list
- CancelledError -> 499 Client Closed Request
- Panic (via catch_unwind) -> 500 Internal Server Error

HANDLER CHAIN:
1. Check for exact type match
2. Check for trait object match
3. Fall back to default handler

title: HTTP TRACE method rejection for security
description:
Explicitly disable HTTP TRACE method to prevent XST (Cross-Site Tracing) attacks. TRACE echoes the request back, which can be used to steal credentials.

**Implementation:**
- Reject TRACE requests with 405 Method Not Allowed
- Log TRACE attempts as potential attack
- No configuration to enable TRACE (security)
- Apply before routing layer

**Security Rationale:**
- TRACE can expose Authorization headers via XSS
- No legitimate use case in modern APIs
- OWASP recommends disabling

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- TRACE requests return 405
- TRACE attempts logged as security event
- All routes reject TRACE
- Cannot be enabled per-route

**Tests:**
- TRACE / returns 405
- TRACE /api/users returns 405
- Security log entry for TRACE attempt

description:

- Trait for wrapping handlers
- Pre-processing (before handler)
- Post-processing (after handler)
- Early return capability
- Access to RequestContext
- Ordering/layering semantics

- Ergonomic impl for common cases
- Tower-like layering (optional)
- Works with async handlers
- Proper error propagation

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Clear middleware trait definition
- Example middleware implementations
- Documented ordering behavior
- Integration with router
close_reason:
Implemented middleware trait design with:
- Middleware trait with before/after hooks
- ControlFlow for short-circuiting
- Handler trait for wrapping handlers
- MiddlewareStack for composing middleware
- Layer pattern for functional composition
- Example middleware: NoopMiddleware, AddResponseHeader, RequireHeader, PathPrefixFilter

title: Rate limiting middleware
description: Configurable rate limiting for API protection. Algorithms: token bucket (default), fixed window, sliding window. Configuration via RateLimit::new().requests(100).per(Duration::from_secs(60)).key_extractor(...). Response headers: X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset, Retry-After. Route-specific limits via #[rate_limit(10, per_minute)] attribute. Backend support: in-memory default, trait for Redis/distributed. Test: verify limiting triggers, headers set, different key extractors, per-route limits.

title: APIRouter for route grouping
description:

ROUTE METHODS:
- router.get('/path', handler)
- router.post('/path', handler)
- router.put/delete/patch/options/head

USAGE:


ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:

- Prefix applied to all routes
- Tags merged with route tags
- Dependencies inherited

TEST REQUIREMENTS:

- Unit: Tag merging
- Unit: Dependency inheritance
- Integration: Nested routers
- Integration: Include in app

title: Response model validation and serialization
description:
Implement response_model parameter for output validation:

ROUTE PARAMETER:
#[get('/users/{id}', response_model = User)]
async fn get_user(id: Path<i64>) -> Json<User>

BEHAVIOR:
1. Handler returns data
2. Validate against response_model
3. Serialize with configured options
4. Return JSON response

SERIALIZATION OPTIONS (per FastAPI):
- response_model_include: Set<String>
- response_model_exclude: Set<String>
- response_model_by_alias: bool
- response_model_exclude_unset: bool
- response_model_exclude_defaults: bool
- response_model_exclude_none: bool

VALIDATION BEHAVIOR:
- If response doesn't match model: 500 Internal Error
- ResponseValidationError (internal, not exposed to client)
- Log the actual error for debugging

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Response validated before sending
- Serialization options work
- 500 on validation failure (not 422)
- Error logged for debugging

TEST REQUIREMENTS:
- Unit: Each serialization option
- Unit: Validation failure handling
- Unit: Include/exclude fields
- Integration: Full response flow

title: HTTPS redirect and enforcement middleware
description:
Force HTTPS connections by redirecting HTTP requests and setting HSTS headers. Critical for production security.

**Implementation:**
- Redirect HTTP to HTTPS (301 or 307)
- HSTS header (Strict-Transport-Security)
- Configurable redirect behavior
- Proxy-aware (X-Forwarded-Proto)
- Exclude health check endpoints

**Configuration:**
- redirect: bool (enable/disable redirects)
- hsts_seconds: int (max-age value)
- include_subdomains: bool
- preload: bool (HSTS preload)
- exclude_paths: Vec<String>

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- HTTP requests redirected to HTTPS
- HSTS header set on HTTPS responses
- Health checks accessible over HTTP
- Proxy headers respected
- Configurable per-environment

**Tests:**
- HTTP GET redirects to HTTPS
- HTTPS GET returns HSTS header
- Health check accessible over HTTP
- X-Forwarded-Proto: https not redirected
- HSTS preload flag works

title: OPTIONS method auto-handling for CORS preflight
description:
Automatically handle OPTIONS requests for CORS preflight. When CORS middleware is enabled, generate correct preflight responses with Access-Control-Allow-Methods, Access-Control-Allow-Headers. For non-CORS OPTIONS, return 204 with Allow header listing supported methods for the route.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- OPTIONS requests handled before route handlers
- Allow header populated with route's methods
- CORS preflight generates correct headers
- OPTIONS disabled on routes where not wanted
- No body in OPTIONS response

**Tests:**
- OPTIONS returns Allow header with GET,POST for route supporting both
- CORS preflight returns Access-Control-Allow-Methods
- OPTIONS on non-existent route returns 404
- OPTIONS on method-restricted route returns only allowed methods

title: Transfer-Encoding handling and hop-by-hop headers
description:
Properly handle Transfer-Encoding (chunked, gzip, etc.) and strip hop-by-hop headers per HTTP spec. Critical for correct proxying and body handling.

**Implementation:**
- Parse Transfer-Encoding header (comma-separated)
- Handle chunked encoding in body parser
- Strip hop-by-hop headers: Connection, Keep-Alive, Proxy-Authenticate, Proxy-Authorization, TE, Trailers, Transfer-Encoding, Upgrade
- Preserve only end-to-end headers in forwarded requests
- Content-Length vs Transfer-Encoding mutual exclusion

**Hop-by-Hop Headers to Strip:**
- Connection
- Keep-Alive
- Proxy-Authenticate
- Proxy-Authorization
- TE
- Trailers
- Transfer-Encoding
- Upgrade

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Chunked requests decoded correctly
- Hop-by-hop headers stripped when proxying
- Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding mutual exclusion enforced
- Trailers supported with chunked encoding

**Tests:**
- Chunked body decoded correctly
- Response with hop-by-hop headers stripped for proxy
- 400 if both Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding present
- Trailers accessible after chunked body

title: NDJSON streaming response for large datasets
description:
Support Newline-Delimited JSON (NDJSON) streaming for returning large datasets incrementally. Essential for data export and real-time feeds.

Implementation:
- NdjsonResponse type
- Accepts Stream/Iterator of serializable items
- Sets Content-Type: application/x-ndjson
- Flushes after each line
- Memory-efficient (no buffering full response)
- Integration with asupersync streaming

Usage Pattern:
- Stream database query results
- Real-time log output
- Incremental data export

Acceptance Criteria:
- Each JSON object on its own line
- Proper Content-Type header
- Streaming starts before all data ready
- Memory stays constant regardless of data size
- Errors mid-stream handled gracefully

Tests:
- 1000 items stream without buffering
- Content-Type is application/x-ndjson
- Each line is valid JSON
- Memory usage stays flat
- Client can parse incrementally

title: Connection header handling (close, keep-alive, upgrade)
description:
Parse and handle Connection header for connection management. Critical for HTTP/1.1 keep-alive and WebSocket upgrades.

**Implementation:**
- Parse Connection header (comma-separated tokens)
- Respect Connection: close to disable keep-alive
- Handle Connection: keep-alive for HTTP/1.0
- Connection: upgrade for WebSocket (future)
- Strip headers listed in Connection header

**Behavior:**
- HTTP/1.1 default: keep-alive
- HTTP/1.0 default: close
- Connection: close overrides keep-alive
- Listed headers stripped from response

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Connection: close disables keep-alive
- HTTP/1.0 with Keep-Alive: works
- Headers listed in Connection stripped
- Default behavior per HTTP version

**Tests:**
- HTTP/1.1 with Connection: close closes after response
- HTTP/1.0 with Connection: keep-alive keeps open
- Custom headers in Connection field stripped
- Multiple connection tokens handled

title: Host header validation and virtual hosting
description:
Validate Host header per HTTP/1.1 spec. Required for security (DNS rebinding protection) and virtual hosting support.

**Implementation:**
- Reject requests without Host header (400)
- Validate Host matches server configuration
- Support multiple allowed hosts
- Reject requests with invalid Host (DNS rebinding)
- Integration with reverse proxy configs

**Security Considerations:**
- Prevent DNS rebinding attacks
- Block requests with mismatched Host
- Log suspicious Host values
- Configurable allowed_hosts list

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- 400 Bad Request if Host header missing
- Request allowed if Host in allowed_hosts
- Request blocked if Host not in allowed_hosts
- Wildcard hosts supported (*.example.com)
- X-Forwarded-Host respected when configured

**Tests:**
- Request without Host gets 400
- Request with allowed Host succeeds
- Request with disallowed Host gets 400
- Wildcard host matching works
- Behind reverse proxy with X-Forwarded-Host

title: DI system test suite
description:
Comprehensive test suite for dependency injection:

TEST CATEGORIES:

1. BASIC RESOLUTION
- Simple dependency resolution
- Multiple dependencies in handler
- Async dependency functions

2. CACHING
- Same dependency returns cached instance
- use_cache=false returns fresh
- Scope isolation (request vs function)

3. NESTED DEPENDENCIES
- A depends on B
- A depends on B, B depends on C
- Diamond: A depends on B and C, both depend on D

4. CLEANUP (YIELD PATTERN)
- Cleanup runs on success
- Cleanup runs on error
- Cleanup runs on panic
- LIFO cleanup order

5. OVERRIDES
- Override replaces dependency
- Override affects nested deps
- Clear overrides works

6. SAFETY
- Circular dependency detection
- Scope constraint validation
- Clear error messages

7. INTEGRATION
- Full request with complex deps
- TestClient with overrides
- Real resource cleanup (files, connections)

COVERAGE TARGET: 95%+ for DI code

title: HTTPException struct and error responses
description:
Implement HTTPException equivalent for user-thrown errors:

STRUCTURE:
- status_code: u16 (required)
- detail: serde_json::Value (optional - string, object, or array)
- headers: Option<HeaderMap> (optional - extra response headers)

BEHAVIOR:
- Can be returned from any handler or extractor
- Automatically converted to HTTP response
- Preserves status code and headers
- JSON body: {"detail": <detail>}

COMMON CONSTRUCTORS:
- HttpError::not_found(detail)
- HttpError::bad_request(detail)
- HttpError::unauthorized() (with WWW-Authenticate)
- HttpError::forbidden(detail)
- HttpError::internal_server_error()

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- HttpError can be returned from handler
- Status code, headers, body all work
- Ergonomic constructors for common cases
- IntoResponse implementation

TEST REQUIREMENTS:
- Unit: Each status code constructor
- Unit: Custom headers
- Unit: Various detail types (string, object)
- Integration: Error response in handler
- Coverage: All common HTTP error codes
close_reason: HTTPException implemented in crates/fastapi-core/src/error.rs: HttpError struct with status, detail, headers; IntoResponse impl; convenience constructors (bad_request, unauthorized, forbidden, not_found, internal)

title: OAuth2AuthorizationCodeBearer extractor
description: OAuth2 Authorization Code flow extractor. Required: authorizationUrl (authorization endpoint), tokenUrl (token endpoint). Optional: refreshUrl, scopes dict, scheme_name, description, auto_error. Extracts Bearer token from Authorization header. OpenAPI security scheme type: oauth2 with authorizationCode flow. Test: verify token extraction, 401 on missing/invalid, OpenAPI schema correct.
